results.title: Don't be let down
results.creator_credit: Joan Hansen, R.D. Hansen, Fortune Film Productions and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1960 government film describes the regulations under the New South Wales Scaffolding and Lifts Act and how they apply in the building industry. Accompanied by an instructional narration, it surveys the correct manufacture, use and storage of wooden ladders in the industry. It outlines the dangers of improper use of ladders, including dramatic stagings of accidental falls through carelessness.

Produced by Fortune Film Productions and the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

There are several jumps in the soundtrack throughout the film due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Don't be incorrectly dressed
results.creator_credit: Ron Collins, Stan Murdoch, Reg Perier and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1962 film demonstrates the need for various types of protective clothing and equipment when working with abrasives, welding, lead and chemicals. Accompanied by an instructional narration, the film shows footage of workers in various industries, and the need for protective glasses, face shields, respirators, gloves, footwear and clothing.

Produced by the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

There are several jumps in the soundtrack throughout the film due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Don't be cut up
results.creator_credit: Joan Hansen, R.D. Hansen, Fortune Film Productions and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1959 film outlines the hazards associated with the metal trade industry. It emphasises the importance of fixed guards on machines including guillotines, bending brakes, power presses and emery wheels. The film is interspersed with title cards including the repeated ‘Accidents need not happen’ and features a voiceover narration dramatically warning against accidents. It is directed at both workers in the factory risking accident and disability, and employers risking loss of production and financial loss.

Produced by Fortune Film Productions and the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Don't be a fall guy
results.creator_credit: Ron Collins, Stan Murdoch, Reg Perier and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1962 instructional film demonstrates safety regulations on building sites in Sydney, New South Wales. Narrated by a didactic voiceover, the film dramatises the do’s and dont’s of construction sites, including good housekeeping, adequate lighting, head protection, guard rails, proper scaffolding and safety lines. It emphasises the risks of carelessness and overconfidence of builders working without proper safety equipment.

In order to demonstrate this, the film restages several accidents, including a man falling down an open lift shaft after the guard rail was removed by a fellow builder. The film also includes footage of riggers climbing steel frames on multi-story buildings without safety harnesses, in what would have been standard practice in this era.

Produced by the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Don't be a carrier
results.creator_credit: Ann Millard, Jack Keane, Australian Agricultural Council and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: Illustrates how plant pests and diseases are spread by the carelessness of travellers carrying fruit, vegetables and plants across State borders. Strict quarantine regulations have been enforced to prevent the spread of disease to the Murray and Barossa Valleys. In South Australia, free of Black Spot and Codlin Moth, the importation of apples from interstate or overseas is prohibited. In recent years, Fruit Fly has been introduced into Victoria and South Australia necessitating costly spraying and destruction of fruit in infected areas, an undertaking which is the result of carelessness of a few individuals in the community.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ann Millard, Jack Keane, Australian Agricultural Council and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture

results.title: Challenging years
results.creator_credit: Peter Fletcher, David E. Barrow, Stanley Hawes, New South Wales Film Corporation and Motion Picture Associates
results.brief_description: Shows how some elderly men and women have planned for retirement. Illustrates, with dramatic vignettes, the positive and rewarding aspects of this period of life, and warns of the pitfalls to be avoided.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Fletcher, David E. Barrow, Stanley Hawes, New South Wales Film Corporation and Motion Picture Associates

results.title: The Challenge
results.creator_credit: Wayne Le Clos, John Carter, Gil Brealey and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: This film deals with a situation in which one man is promoted over an another who has more experience in the same area. The man overlooked displays his resentment by insisting that nothing has changed and that he will continue to behave as he has always done. The question posed concerns the preservation of old relationships after promotion while making it clear that one is now boss. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Wayne Le Clos, John Carter, Gil Brealey and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: A Busy sort of bloke: Harold Hughan
results.creator_credit: Crafts Council of Australia, Lindsay Frazer, Gillian Armstrong and Australia Council
results.brief_description: The simplicity and charm of the man and his work are portrayed in this film, which shows Harold Hughan at home and at work. He is seen making a platter, and he discusses the objective of his pieces made with clay. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Birth of a monster
results.creator_credit: John Lamond, Ian Crawford and Zanthus Films
results.brief_description: Ocean Digger an off-shore oil drilling rig is the monster - ugly, unwieldy, gigantic, with a mammoth job to do in the off-shore search for oil and gas. Her construction, launching and fitting out at the Whyalla shipyards are shown in detail. Narrated by Terry Norris.

results.title: Behind the switch
results.creator_credit: Neil Howe, Shan Benson and State Electricity Commission of Victoria
results.brief_description: Every switch is a demand for instant electricity. Shows how this demand is met in Victoria. The Latrobe Valley brown coal provides four-fifths of electricity. Shows work at Yallourn and Morwell and progress on the new Hazelwood power station. Use of electricity in industry, at home, for transport, and entertainment. Increasing demands are a measure of the State’s growth and rate of development. Emphasis on ability to meet future demands.
